document.title: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards for Mathematics

F6287B1864F74D0CBE6C546F5396292C.description: Multiply a matrix by a scalar.¬†

0DEC3CFBAFF9498897BBB0390610E7E8.description: Add and subtract matrices of the same size.

45742CCB4AF040D9A76834A62EBF40C1.description: Recognize that a ùëö √ó ùëõ matrix has ùëö rows and ùëõ columns.

65006E23B1E84871817038258825D31E.description: Understand that a matrix is a way to organize data.¬†

FADF26A6A41D4B37AB2AE6E3775C8BF5.description:
Organize data in matrices with rational numbers and apply to real-world and
 mathematical situations.

0DDDF574417C46F69F65A221E1AD6387.description: Explore patterns of possible association between the two categorical variables.

72072B73F4EB45D1A1A391471D81C6A3.description: Interpret data in two-way tables using relative frequencies.

6EF5D9D4F80C48918F3A9E3421B45D82.description: Organize bivariate categorical data in a two-way table

6F2074CA27CE4A40B716B51F93FC6C2F.description: Investigate bivariate categorical data in two-way tables.¬†

D3DFA91247424412B7D90941C014D632.description:
Find an approximate equation for the line of best fit using two appropriate data
points.

30F6F42FAB75467792333A16F6C905F5.description: Apply concepts of an approximate line of best fit in real-world situations.

A25996F5844341848AFE89FA73913847.description:
Draw an approximate line of best fit on a scatter plot that appears to have a linear
association and informally assess the fit of the line to the data points.¬†

44EA21629B3C4B7CA92900C8846C7D5B.description:
Describe patterns observed on a scatter plot, including clustering, outliers, and
association (positive, negative, no correlation, linear, nonlinear).

1C7A78C58AEF4EEB8DF18E54D96EC9F2.description: Graph the bivariate data on a scatter plot.

FE196C9871904C87A46F3DA21CC4F106.description:
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving volumes of cones, cylinders,
and spheres and the surface area of cylinders.¬†

539B5BC15E0C450698451FA5FD6EF39B.description:
Find the distance between any two points in the coordinate plane using the
Pythagorean Theorem.¬†

15CE3F1B5F224E57B12B1E6029474A3D.description:
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to model and solve real-world and mathematical
problems in two and three dimensions involving right triangles.¬†

7A1D182895E9427C9783F31E66556CB6.description: Use models to demonstrate a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse.¬†

5E4584E21F5E4E3789D3272365ABF52D.description: Recognize that two similar figures have congruent corresponding angles

0F89E8C820D14101806ADA537B7F4997.description:
Identify congruent and supplementary pairs of angles when two parallel lines are
cut by a transversal.

59C370E4700E486E89CC910EA7ABDCDA.description:
Discover and use the relationship between interior and exterior angles of a
triangle.

7BBD40792C234568BCE34DD1CD51E935.description: Discover that the sum of the three angles in a triangle is 180 degrees.

BC5B6D96503D49A1BBF5BD309F6A8C23.description:
Extend and apply previous knowledge of angles to properties of triangles, similar
figures, and parallel lines cut by a transversal.

D9E26905C3004AEF8E7A0F9F75EF9993.description:
Use proportional reasoning to find the missing side lengths of two similar
figures.

FFE036CD0FA3443CBE2CD9736F01CB40.description:
Given two similar figures, describe the series of transformations that justifies this
similarity.

AF89160F1AA94A9B8DC677DAA1D040B2.description:
Recognize that two-dimensional figures are only similar if a series of
transformations can be performed to map the pre-image to the image.¬†

C7A2E70B61A04691AF57E7C744852503.description: Dilate geometric figures using scale factors that are positive rational numbers.

D565D2A516604FF7BEC19D90F530708B.description: Apply the properties of transformations (rotations, reflections, translations, dilations).¬†

65C1CEEB292D4421A5F300B3D6BE1A4E.description: Relate scale drawings to dilations of geometric figures.

0510FC5FBDDB416CB0178B58C9C61C60.description: Use coordinate geometry to describe the effect of transformations on two-dimensional figures.

47CF29B85E464B3E82AB63D01D8E8F73.description:
Investigate the properties of transformations (rotations, reflections, translations,
dilations) using a variety of tools (e.g., grid paper, reflective devices, graphing paper,
dynamic software).

0359D15A842E4184B462DA9B59CFEDB0.description:
Given two congruent figures, describe the series of rigid transformations that
justifies this congruence.

D467247E64D54202B7814B9E0D6890D5.description:
Recognize that two-dimensional figures are only congruent if a series of rigid
transformations can be performed to map the pre-image to the image.

F0CB71B7A6BF450CB970D59F9F39A9A6.description: Translate geometric figures vertically and/or horizontally.

5AE3B0F15F51483BB349EA57A72CFD27.description: . Reflect geometric figures with respect to the ùë•-axis and/or ùë¶-axis.

A7120E4C0AE8445AB7ABF8D5C3A55C1F.description:
Rotate geometric figures 90, 180, and 270 degrees, both clockwise and
counterclockwise, about the origin.

EBF898EDF7954A03B53445EFBA1A041C.description: Apply the properties of rigid transformations (rotations, reflections, translations).¬†

4074A9EC298E4070B29E2977DA758391.description: Verify that corresponding line segments are congruent

589FE4392957467FA355B9EB00DD3E50.description: Verify that corresponding angles are congruent.

D1137F13B6AA422BA3BA095C8AB07615.description: Verify that lines are mapped to lines, including parallel lines.

6232D32757274B709812C8313D875E87.description:
Understand that systems of linear equations can have one solution, no solution,
or infinitely many solutions.

E8DA45807C4A477994DA7027E10A3837.description:
Solve systems of linear equations algebraically, including methods of
substitution and elimination, or through inspection.¬†

2B2C1DDDE36E4B75BA87FE1B7A12E9E8.description:
Understand and verify that a solution to a system of linear equations is
represented on a graph as the point of intersection of the two lines.

F5B3FAF857824906A24B91F46C5B4286.description: Graph systems of linear equations and estimate their point of intersection.

37804473E7034ECDAEC9133568B9BA27.description:
Investigate and solve real-world and mathematical problems involving systems of
linear equations in two variables with integer coefficients and solutions.

B3C25885DA6A41A89B5BDFD82CFD99C2.description: Justify why linear equations have a specific type of solution.

68507846CE2C44AFB4DDE6203B39E799.description: Generate linear equations with the three types of solutions.

4B45141902A24430A246616A6A530D82.description:
Recognize the three types of solutions to linear equations: one solution (ùë• = ùëé),
infinitely many solutions (ùëé = ùëé), or no solutions (ùëé = ùëè).

567ED33046F946F2822668E7DA6CC6AC.description:
Solve linear equations and inequalities with rational number coefficients that
include the use of the distributive property, combining like terms, and variables
on both sides.

782B60080242421CA460BCAC97025ACE.description:
Extend concepts of linear equations and inequalities in one variable to more complex
multi-step equations and inequalities in real-world and mathematical situations.¬†

3E4675548B3642BBAEFEB6D6F91859EA.description:
Relate equations for proportional relationships (ùë¶ = ùëòùë•) with the slope-intercept
form (ùë¶ = ùëöùë• + ùëè) where ùëè = 0.

C63D2BEF86AE474C950599D28BE53272.description: Derive the slope-intercept form (ùë¶ = ùëöùë• + ùëè) for a non-vertical line.

128AA1436E014B54A598807D89AD1E11.description: Explain why the slope, ùëö, is the same between any two distinct points on a nonvertical line using similar triangles.

FF43205093054751809BDF14751F2CC1.description:
Apply concepts of slope and ùë¶-intercept to graphs, equations, and proportional
relationships.

89109147589A4FB385864445A728BA9D.description:
Compare two different proportional relationships given multiple representations,
including tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions.

E103934F0D6C4621B5C78F97B402D525.description: Interpret unit rate as the slope of the graph.

449FBFEAF8D943C8A92DBDAD18E19917.description: Apply concepts of proportional relationships to real-world and mathematical situations.¬†

88D706502EA04075AEFB21C3274C1797.description:
Translate how different technological devices display numbers in scientific
notation.

A72E4C2A4A564708BC0D71B6BCA9D784.description:
Select appropriate units of measure when representing answers in scientific
notation.

AF108B690DF64948AAB885680F3433AE.description: Multiply and divide numbers expressed in both decimal and scientific notation.

353EE6904457422F8BB13428A69FFD97.description:
Apply the concepts of decimal and scientific notation to solve real-world and
mathematical problems.¬†

571D6DDC05C04BD4B80B07E25E3A1D46.description: Estimate and compare the relative size of two quantities in scientific notation.

D6E01B255E4146A3BD25FEF1CC5CA3D7.description: Translate between decimal notation and scientific notation.¬†

4F889FFDCE344CFD840B396F68E63E5B.description:
Express very large and very small quantities in scientific notation in the form
ùëé √ó 10ùëè = ùëù where 1 ‚â§ ùëé < 10 and ùëè is an integer.

780774E421CA41A4B04F8BB3F801F85D.description: Explore the relationship between quantities in decimal and scientific notation.¬†

D5B6A010DFA048C2A1D0F825B70654E0.description: Recognize that square roots of non-perfect squares are irrational.

622E847896F04DDAA8491B9592D92F81.description: Evaluate cube roots of perfect cubes.

1464C699B3CB476DA2D74AFDA70E55D1.description:
Find the exact and approximate solutions to equations of the form ùë•
2 = ùëù and
ùë•
3 = ùëù where ùëù is a positive rational number.

203CBCDFD9A24DCBA96E385134584517.description: Investigate concepts of square and cube roots.¬†

52AC5430B9E34D29A911D60E3DB0E25B.description:
Understand and apply the laws of exponents (i.e., product rule, quotient rule, power to
a power, product to a power, quotient to a power, zero power property, negative
exponents) to simplify numerical expressions that include integer exponents.

9210002AF0F04690A3306271CE6120F4.description: Write a verbal description from the graph of a function with and without scales.

E29840105E1242F598281A07EC2AD4DC.description: Sketch the graph of a function from a verbal description.

F4AE97A8DCB94F45913253D61578A66C.description:
Analyze and describe attributes of graphs of functions (e.g., constant,
increasing/decreasing, linear/nonlinear, maximum/minimum,
discrete/continuous).

FD5CFD3D0ABE4A698409DC86DD007E94.description:
Apply the concepts of linear and nonlinear functions to graphs in real-world and
mathematical situations.

B12865607FE1441AAB05A90CA410C854.description: Explore the relationship between linear functions and arithmetic sequences.

0F4EFC8E626240D2A35EFDA85BB1ED90.description:
Interpret the meaning of the slope and the ùë¶-intercept of a linear function in the
context of the situation.

2986FDE2F5D846699B888E60DB517D38.description:
Construct a function in slope-intercept form that models a linear relationship
between two quantities.

A55B3C1E176F44D188FEF111F382B606.description:
Determine the slope and the ùë¶-intercept of a linear function given multiple
representations, including two points, tables, graphs, equations, and verbal
descriptions.

6D01AD74B81D4F849DCEE0F928A7AAA1.description:
Understand that the slope is the constant rate of change and the ùë¶-intercept is the
point where ùë• = 0.

9D05CC824E3F47DBA6747CD8113A2CC4.description: Apply the concepts of linear functions to real-world and mathematical situations.¬†

D4FBDB8FB02E47818BD500A3093E3804.description: Recognize that the graph of a linear function has a constant rate of change.

A125BDDC49804C33AB0B455882B44C1B.description:
Define an equation in slope-intercept form (ùë¶ = ùëöùë• + ùëè) as being a linear
function.

3BFED364B1254EEAA7E2B6E89527981A.description:
Investigate the differences between linear and nonlinear functions using multiple
representations (i.e., tables, graphs, equations, and verbal descriptions).

00FED586162647B58BFF70494CE646D7.description:
Compare multiple representations of two functions, including mappings, tables, graphs,
equations, and verbal descriptions, in order to draw conclusions.

4DCF3DFFB3BB4020884D582424CF6B76.description:
Graph a function from a table of values. Understand that the graph and table both
represent a set of ordered pairs of that function.

BDBED2B4AC02466EA4619FD70AA769C4.description:
Determine if a relation is a function using multiple representations, including
mappings, tables, graphs, equations, and verbal descriptions.¬†

071064EB930B4AC39C7C3C13BC0D285A.description:
Translate among the multiple representations of a function, including mappings,
tables, graphs, equations, and verbal descriptions.

E987E64E673B4B72AD867A25DE876330.description:
¬†Relate inputs (ùë•-values or domain) and outputs (ùë¶-values or range) to
independent and dependent variables.¬†

CEFDA04639CC4A90A0EA7D9F5752E504.description: Understand that a function assigns to each input exactly one output.

EFD90056B6BB4D3CACC56B20F5F4151B.description:
Extend prior knowledge to translate among multiple representations of rational
numbers (fractions, decimal numbers, percentages). Include the conversion of
repeating decimal numbers to fractions.

5776B07073B44E428D1355DD87888FB8.description:
Estimate and compare the value of irrational numbers by plotting them on a number
line.¬†

5F80752561DD4B29892BEB7C67B5239F.description:
Model the hierarchy of the real number system, including natural, whole, integer,
rational, and irrational numbers.

F1A3E37315E74737A7C74E54BC575481.description: Understand that all real numbers have a decimal expansion.

326DACD29AA042E8947D01D0B7FDA390.description: Recognize the differences between rational and irrational numbers.

31320F20A8F1425D9F3A4E0EDB15E5E3.description: Explore the real number system and its appropriate usage in real-world situations.¬†
